title: Why should a compound not be heated to the point that it melts? - Quora

response.answer_text: Um. because it will melt? The question has no context and so there is no way anyone can actually answer this. If it’s a steel girder holding up a bridge then OK. don’t melt the steel girder. If the question is just some general question then I don’t know. You tell me… Why can’t you? What did you hear? Perhaps with some context I might figure out what you’re getting at. In general, I put ice in my drink and watch it melt with absolute no terror that I’m doing something wrong. Welders melt steel as part of their job, Candy makers regularly melt things as part of the cooking processes.

In the organic lab, we almost always heat the compound to the melting point to determine the identity and purity of the sample. Some compounds decompose or explode on heating, and those should not be heated to melting!
